description: The round payoff this round was 5. You, John chose to play option 2.Kate chose to play option 2. You received a payoff of -5000.

In this game, choosing option2 is a high‐risk, high‐reward move. If you are the only one picking option2 while your opponent defaults to option1, you gain the round’s input value (here, 5). However, if both players choose option2—like in the memory from 2024‑01‑02—you both incur a massive penalty (here, –5000, which comes from 5×1000). This shows that deviation from the default can backfire severely if reciprocated.

The opponent, Deepseek‑R1, is designed to default to option1 and is aware of your default choice. This common knowledge implies that as long as you stick to the default, mutual safe behavior will likely be maintained. Nonetheless, any deviation (i.e. playing option2) introduces risk, as Deepseek‑R1 might also adapt or, in some circumstances, choose option2, resulting in a disastrous outcome.

The memory from 2024‑01‑02 offers a practical lesson: even if the round input is moderate (here, 5), the multiplication factor on mutual deviation (×1000) means that small miscoordination can translate into enormous losses. This emphasizes the importance of trusting default behaviors or only deviating when you are sure the opponent will stick to option1.
